sense.def: unpleasant to look at
dictionaryExamples: an ugly building/city
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are lots of trees and bushes, [and] lots of fresh air, but the city itself is quite ugly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Romanian

sense.def: An ugly situation is very unpleasant, usually because it involves violence.
dictionaryExamples: There were ugly scenes outside the stadium.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Just think about the ugly situation of being in a fully-booked hotel and then the staff goes on strike. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: better, greater or worse than all similar things
dictionaryExamples: Climbing Mount Everest is the ultimate challenge.
the ultimate luxury cruise
For me, rats are the ultimate horror.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being on the road is always better than the arrival, so this journey would be the ultimate journey for me as well. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: final or most important
dictionaryExamples: the ultimate aim/goal
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But, for me, the ultimate thrill would be the fact that people would use the software that I had made. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: finally, after a series of things have happened
dictionaryExamples: Everything will ultimately depend on what is said at the meeting with the directors next week.
Ultimately, of course, he'd like to have his own business but that won't be for some time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ultimately, it leads to a lot of d[i]seases and early death. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: used to emphasize the most important fact in a situation
dictionaryExamples: Ultimately, he'll have to decide.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ultimately, that is why we are influenced by other people's personalities. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a thing that you hold above your head to keep yourself dry when it is raining
dictionaryExamples: I felt a few spots of rain so I put my umbrella up.
I left my umbrella on the bus yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got some books, a bottle of wine and an umbrella. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: too bad to be allowed to continue
dictionaryExamples: The water contains unacceptable levels of pollution.
I find that kind of behavior completely unacceptable.
The teacher's union has described the latest contract offer as unacceptable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So I waited for 45 minutes until the show started. [T]hat is an unacceptable delay. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: not changed by something
dictionaryExamples: Smaller colleges will be unaffected by the new regulations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only a genius could stay unaffected by such idolatry. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: too expensive for people to be able to buy
dictionaryExamples: Such clothes are unaffordable for most people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Regarding the gift shop, most of the students admit that there was most interesting technology in there, but on the other hand the things offered were unaffordable for us. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Zulu

sense.def: agreed by everyone
dictionaryExamples: The jury was unanimous in finding him guilty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having spoken to neighbors, we reached a unanimous decision that the route of the aircraft should be changed im[m]ediately so that they no longer disrupt our lives. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: with agreement from everyone
dictionaryExamples: We agreed unanimously that he was the best candidate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While it is true that there are quite a few opposing theories about losing weight, doctors unanimously agree that a hedonistic approach to eating can lead to unpleasant health issues like obesity. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian

sense.def: not able to be achieved
dictionaryExamples: an unattainable ideal
Some economists think that full employment in Europe is an unattainable goal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The ability to permanently record thought opened new dimensions to fields like philosophy, poetry and literature, enabling them to reach a degree of complexity, creativity and longevity unattainable by previous technologies. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: not beautiful or pleasant to look at
dictionaryExamples: I felt old and unattractive.
Their new building is very unattractive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This information is useful for [a person] who thinks his/her body is unattractive. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: not interesting or useful
dictionaryExamples: an unattractive proposition
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In our opinion, despite the friendly atmosphere of our club's meetings we find them very unattractive and rather "dull." Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: impossible to buy or get
dictionaryExamples: The book is unavailable until January.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The third point was that the discount[ed] tickets were unavailable. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: not able to talk to someone or meet them, especially because you are doing other things
dictionaryExamples: The manager was unavailable for comment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, a role-model for the younger generation could be the famous tennis player Joe Hill, who unfortunately is unavailable to give an interview. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: impossible to avoid or prevent
dictionaryExamples: an unavoidable delay
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being aware of the two proposals our local government is considering in order to solve the apparently unavoidable matter of traffic in our beloved city, I feel compelled to offer my views on such a delicate subject. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: in a way that could not be avoided or prevented
dictionaryExamples: She was unavoidably delayed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people believe that thinking about poor consequences can unavoidably lead to them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: not knowing about something
dictionaryExamples: He was unaware that the police were watching him.
I was completely unaware of the problem.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although you may be an expert in one subject you can be unaware [of] some basics in others. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: slightly mentally ill
dictionaryExamples: After his death, she became slightly unbalanced.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many homeless people are mentally unbalanced, some are addicted to chemical substances. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: false and not fair
dictionaryExamples: He gave an unbalanced view of the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that if a school measures a child solely by his or her academic success, it will be an unbalanced and narrow-minded method to measure a child and his or her ability as a whole person. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: too painful or unpleasant for you to continue to experience
dictionaryExamples: The heat was almost unbearable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Life can be very difficult, almost unbearable sometimes. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: extremely bad or good and making you feel surprised
dictionaryExamples: It's unbelievable how lucky she's been.
You've had such bad luck - it's unbelievable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The food is unbelievable and I'm sure you'll love it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: not probable and difficult to believe
dictionaryExamples: I found most of the characters in the play totally unbelievable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They made up unbelievable stories which almost made them cry in the end. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: able to judge fairly because you are not influenced by your own opinions
dictionaryExamples: He was able to give me some unbiased advice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you take into consideration only certain subjects, you are likely to end up despising other fields of knowledge, whereas the main point of education is to give an unbiased view of our own and foreign cultures. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: not sure or not able to decide about something
dictionaryExamples: He's uncertain whether to go to graduate school or not.
Beth was uncertain about meeting him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [There are] things that I am uncertain about, and [that I would] be grateful if you c[ould] explain. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: not known or fixed, or not completely certain
dictionaryExamples: New arrivals face an uncertain future.
The political outlook is still uncertain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please do not bother posting them since we do not have a zip code where I live, and they might get lost with our uncertain Post Service. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: in a direct and often angry way
dictionaryExamples: I told him to go away in no uncertain terms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Intellectuals are used to saying in no uncertain terms that money represents the bad side of the sport. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the state of being uncertain
dictionaryExamples: There was a lot of uncertainty about whether or not he would attend the event.
Life is full of uncertainties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The shortages of almost everything we have to face and cope with have made our lives full of uncertainty and helplessness, but on the other hand they released in some Poles enormous energy, in the effort to support their families and provide them with food, clothing and fuel. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: staying the same
dictionaryExamples: The area has remained virtually unchanged in fifty years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the big and small things which defin[e] people's personal environment will be left nearly unchanged - the furniture, the pictures on the wall.... I suppose our future homes will be a mix of new technologies and good old tradition. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the brother of your mother or father, or the husband of your aunt
dictionaryExamples: I have an uncle who lives there.
Did you bring me a present, Uncle Jack?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My uncle gave me the best present. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: not easy to understand
dictionaryExamples: The situation at the moment is unclear.
It's unclear what actually happened that night.
It's unclear whether he arrived before or after the shot was fired.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If something is unclear please give me a call. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: If you are unclear about something, you are not certain about it.
dictionaryExamples: I'm unclear about a couple of points in your proposal - could you go over them again?

sense.def: not feeling comfortable and pleasant, or not making you feel comfortable and pleasant
dictionaryExamples: I've eaten so much, I'm really uncomfortable.
These shoes are very uncomfortable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The thing[s] I most hate wearing are shirts, I think they're very uncomfortable.  Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: slightly embarrassed, or making you feel slightly embarrassed
dictionaryExamples: an uncomfortable silence
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is interesting how people get embar[r]assed and uncomfortable when they have to face an English speech. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: in a way that is not comfortable or pleasant
dictionaryExamples: I was warm but not uncomfortably so.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I saw faces I see every day, but in uncomfortably long dresses and with starched white collars, I saw their effort to look nice, attractive and not to disturb the rules set by the society of their time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Serbian

sense.def: unusual
dictionaryExamples: It's not uncommon for people to become ill when they travel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: NEW TRENDS: Vegetarian food is not uncommon nowadays. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: done or given without any limits and without asking for anything for yourself
dictionaryExamples: unconditional love
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But I am of [the] firm conviction that you cannot love [a child] too much, and this unconditional love does not include any rod, in both [the] literal and figurative sense of the word. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: in a state as though you are sleeping, for example because you have been hit on the head
dictionaryExamples: An explosion knocked him unconscious.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the morning, Mrs Crozier went to visit Miss Appleford in number 42 only to find her lying on the floor unconscious. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: An unconscious thought or feeling is one that you are not aware that you have.
dictionaryExamples: an unconscious fear
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe it was her strict upbringing that had left her with an unconscious need to rebel, and that in turn caused her to be drawn to this rowdy young man. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: If you do something unconsciously, you do it without knowing that you are doing it.
dictionaryExamples: She was nodding her head, unconsciously urging him on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is so because every human unconsciously chooses clothes that correspond to their approach to life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: doing things in a way that is different from most people
dictionaryExamples: an unconventional lifestyle
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: CHILDREN'S STORIES This event was successful and satisfied the kids since the heroes were exhilarating, with amazingly unconventional behavior. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a noun that does not have a plural form and cannot be used with "a" or "one"
dictionaryExamples: "Information" and "furniture" are uncountable nouns.

sense.def: to discover something that had been secret or hidden
dictionaryExamples: The inspectors uncovered evidence of corruption.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sitting in a restaurant and discussing provisions of the contract you will find much easier and feel happier than [just sitting] and look[ing] at [an] enormous number of clauses, trying unsuccessfuly to uncover what your client really thought when he wrote this or that. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: certainly true
dictionaryExamples: an undeniable fact
the undeniable truth
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is undeniable that he has made a positive contribution to [the] history of my country. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: in a way that is almost certainly true
dictionaryExamples: He is undeniably the best student we have ever had.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, it will undeniably involve some substantial initial expenditure for opening a cafeteria, but the final result will definitely offset this. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: below something, or below the surface of something
dictionaryExamples: He hid under the bed.
They were standing under a tree.
She was holding a file under her arm.
She pushed her bag under the table.
He could only keep his head under the water for a few seconds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like my bedroom, because there [is] a table under the window, [and] some pictures on the wall. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic

sense.def: less than a number, amount, or age
dictionaryExamples: All items cost/are under a dollar.
You can buy the whole set of DVDs for just under $50.
The discount applies only to children under (the age of) ten.
Under-5s get in free.
If you get under 50%, you've failed the exam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I saw an advertisement in front of my house: the coffee bar is looking for some waiters aged under 23 years old. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: in a particular state or condition
dictionaryExamples: The President is under pressure to resign.
Under no circumstances should the festival become too specialized.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am used to working under pressure. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: being affected by something at this time
dictionaryExamples: The base is once again under attack.
The cause of the fire is still under investigation.
A new 40-story building is under construction.
Several different plans are under discussion.
We are working hard to get the situation under control.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everything was under control, the remote detonator had worked perfectly well. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to think or understand a particular stated thing
dictionaryExamples: I was under the impression (that) you didn't get along very well.
He was under the mistaken impression (that) you were married.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am under the impression that people generally exercise a little, but if they eat the wrong food every day, it won't help. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: If you say something under your breath, you say it very quietly so that other people cannot clearly hear it.
dictionaryExamples: "It's time to go," she muttered under her breath.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "We must have taken a wrong turn somewhere..." he kept muttering under his breath. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If something bad happens under your nose, it happens close to you but you do not notice it.
dictionaryExamples: They were stealing money from under my nose.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You will be surprised that there was something right under your nose that you could not live without. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to be already happening
dictionaryExamples: Building work is already under way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sociologists are well-aware of the fact and experiments are under way to counterbalance these disadvantages. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: not having an advanced level of technology or industry
dictionaryExamples: They are working in underdeveloped parts of the city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A shift of focus in underdeveloped and developing states' economic and social policies is vital to overcoming the problems which cause homelessness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: to fail to understand how large, strong, or important something is
dictionaryExamples: Many people underestimate the cost of owning a car.
We shouldn't underestimate the part that exercise plays in good health.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The report also seemed to underestimate the number of people that had attended. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to not understand how powerful, smart, or skilled someone is
dictionaryExamples: I thought it would be an easy game but I had underestimated my opponent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the beginning she will ask you many questions about yourself. But don't underestimate Ms. Bates (that's her name). Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to experience something, especially a change or medical treatment
dictionaryExamples: The country is currently undergoing major political change.
He is undergoing surgery/therapy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, my country is undergoing a very difficult financial and social situation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to draw a line under a word or sentence, especially in order to show its importance
dictionaryExamples: All the technical words have been underlined in red.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And, another disadvantage in my opinion is that is more difficult to underline or to write some notes if you study from the computer. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to emphasize the truth or importance of something
dictionaryExamples: The report underlines the need for more teachers in schools.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is true that museums do not show the past as well as they could, but we must underline that they are always good enough if we are really interested in knowing about our past. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: An underlying reason or problem is the real reason or problem, although it is not obvious.
dictionaryExamples: We need to look at the underlying reasons for ill health.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The underlying reason is of course a lurking threat of death and decay, which keeps sc[ie]ntists investigating new methods to postpone the age of death. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to make someone less confident or make something weaker
dictionaryExamples: A series of scandals have undermined people's confidence in the government.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All this doesn't undermine the importance of charity workers and entertainers in our work for the greater good. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Serbian

sense.def: under or below something
dictionaryExamples: The tunnel goes right underneath the bay.
They found a bomb underneath the car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was dressed like a princess, after spending the whole day looking for an appropriate dress, which she finally managed to find underneath her bed. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: under or below
dictionaryExamples: He was wearing a dark jacket with a red shirt underneath.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The rock was about 70m high and there was water underneath. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: not earning enough for your work
dictionaryExamples: Her staff felt they were underpaid.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They claim that they are overworked and underpaid (it's [the] usual reason for striking, isn't it?) Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a piece of underwear that covers the area between your waist and the top of your legs
dictionaryExamples: I need some new underpants.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Was that woman me, standing there in those ugly-looking underpants, but with a smart sports bra, with everybody laughing around her? First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a piece of underwear that covers the upper part of the body and you wear under a shirt
dictionaryExamples: As a gift for the new baby she brought tiny undershirts in three sizes.

sense.def: to know the meaning of something that someone says
dictionaryExamples: She explained the whole idea again, but I still didn't understand.
I don't understand half of what he says.
Is there anyone here who understands Arabic?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My teacher help[s] me when I don't understand. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Lithuanian

sense.def: to know why or how something happens or works, or how to do something
dictionaryExamples: We still don't fully understand how the brain works.
I don't understand why my computer crashes so often.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The teacher expla[i]ned her plan for teaching and we understood how to plan our time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Pashto

sense.def: to know how someone feels or why they behave in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: I don't understand James sometimes.
I understand why she's so angry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe now you can understand why I hate shopping. kisses, Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that you believe something is true because someone has told you it is
dictionaryExamples: I understand that the school is due to close next year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I understand that the job entails enterta[in]ing people. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to say something to someone in a way that they understand
dictionaryExamples: I had a little difficulty making myself understood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: (Find enclosed a paper slip on which I have written a destination, number of tickets, etc., in the German language - use it just in case you can't make yourselves understood.) Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: An  understandable feeling or action is one that you would expect in that particular situation.
dictionaryExamples: "I still feel really angry about it." "That's understandable."
Their refusal to help is perfectly/completely understandable, considering the circumstances.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I guess they wouldn't give me permission [to stay] at a female friend's home, but that's understandable. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: in a way that is expected in a particular situation
dictionaryExamples: She's understandably upset.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, the use of the computer system caused long waiting times because everyone wanted - understandably - to find out more about suitable working opportunities. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: knowledge about a subject, situation, etc. or about how something works
dictionaryExamples: She doesn't have any understanding of politics.
My understanding of the agreement  is that they will pay $80,000 over two years.
It was my understanding that she would come alone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was my understanding that discounts were available on the tickets, as the advertisement showed, but there were no discounts. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: sympathy
dictionaryExamples: Thank you for your understanding - I do appreciate it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you for your understanding. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: an informal agreement between two people
dictionaryExamples: The two sides have come to/reached an understanding about the sale of the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I intend to express my dis[s]atisfaction [with] your services through the present letter, and [to] reach an understanding from which I could be compensated. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: showing sympathy for someone's problems
dictionaryExamples: Fortunately, my boss  is very understanding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are famous, but they need to be alone sometimes. I think [the] media must be more understanding. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to do or begin to do something, especially something that will take a long time or be difficult
dictionaryExamples: Students are required to undertake simple experiments.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To achieve it the above mentioned steps should be undertaken. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: to decide or agree to do something
dictionaryExamples: She undertook to organize the meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the last meeting of Our Neighborhood Club we discussed the actions you could undertake to make this situation more bearable. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a difficult or important piece of work, especially one that takes a long time
dictionaryExamples: Building your own house is a major undertaking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While such an undertaking is most advisable, I should like to point out that there may be drawbacks. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: under the surface of water
dictionaryExamples: an underwater camera
Seals can hear very well underwater.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you have diving equipment, you will spend a very good time underwater. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: If something is underway, it is happening.
dictionaryExamples: Economic recovery is already underway.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather was beautif[u]l and the sun sh[one] but as soon as I was underway, the weather turned on us and grew worse with every step. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to begin
dictionaryExamples: The film festival gets underway on July 11th.

sense.def: the clothes that you wear next to your skin, under your other clothes
dictionaryExamples: They sell a wide range of underwear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I see some nice underwear, I will buy it too. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: Something that is undesirable is not wanted because it is bad or unpleasant.
dictionaryExamples: an undesirable influence
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In this day and age, man is inextricably interwoven with the undesirable environmental damage, and the problems as far as the environment is concerned have generated a great deal of heated debate. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: Undeveloped land has no buildings on it and is not used for anything.
dictionaryExamples: The site is still undeveloped.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Town Council decided to take measures in order to benefit our area, which has remained undeveloped for the last five years. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to open something that is fastened or tied
dictionaryExamples: The buttons on her dress are hard to undo.
Can you undo this knot for me?
Can someone help me undo my seat belt?

sense.def: to make a computer get rid of the last change you made to a document and make it the way it was before
dictionaryExamples: You need to undo that change.

sense.def: used to emphasize that something is true
dictionaryExamples: Stress has undoubtedly contributed to her illness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Indeed, children, regardless of what kind of family they grow up in, have the right to be taught to prepare themselves [for] dealing with the real world and the problems that come with it.  This is still undoubtedly every family's obligation whether wealthy or poor, and there are no exceptions. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: to remove your clothes or someone else's clothes
dictionaryExamples: She undressed the children and put them to bed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The chair is for my clothes when I undress. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: not wearing any clothes
dictionaryExamples: I got undressed and went to bed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We got undressed quicker than ever and ran into the waterfall. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: more than is necessary
dictionaryExamples: I don't want to cause undue alarm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, not only do they save time, but also they do it without undue effort since it is not difficult or tiring any more to clean or cook Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: worried because you think something bad might happen
dictionaryExamples: I feel a little uneasy about her traveling alone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway I was getting uneasy because of all that silence, so I began to sing. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: not having a job that provides money
dictionaryExamples: He's been unemployed for over a year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have been unemployed for four months. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: people who are unemployed
dictionaryExamples: We want to get the unemployed back into work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am a lawyer and not so long ago I worked in Poznan Unemployment Office where I happened to use English - not talking to the unemployed of course. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: the number of people who are unemployed
dictionaryExamples: a rise/fall in unemployment
Unemployment has fallen/risen again for the third month in a row.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Later, after a discussion about unemployment, we did reading, writing and listening. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: morally bad
dictionaryExamples: unethical business methods
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, if you would like to perform an experiment, you cannot, because that would be unethical. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: not level, smooth, or in equal amounts
dictionaryExamples: an uneven floor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the same time we must solve the financial problems incurred by the uneven age distribution.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: without problems and without anything exciting happening
dictionaryExamples: The journey itself was fairly uneventful.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This rather quiet and uneventful life changed when we moved to the city. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: not expected
dictionaryExamples: His death was completely unexpected.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last week I had an unexpected visit from my best friend - Mark. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: in a way or at a time that is not expected
dictionaryExamples: Retail sales unexpectedly fell last month.
He announced his resignation unexpectedly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He called me really unexpectedly at work, and told me to go [to] his office at once. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: not treating people in a equal way
dictionaryExamples: an unfair system
The test was unfair because some people had seen it before.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He [always] gave me horrible marks and was very unfair. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: not true and morally wrong
dictionaryExamples: It's unfair to blame Roger for everything.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, it's unfair [to] say that there is nothing to do in the evenings, because there is lots to do. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: in an unfair way

sense.def: not known to you
dictionaryExamples: I noticed several unfamiliar faces in the meeting room.

sense.def: to not have any knowledge or experience of something

dictionaryExamples: This kind of cooking is very unfashionable now.

sense.def: negative and showing that you do not like something

sense.def: not good and likely to cause problems

sense.def: not good enough or not having the qualities needed or expected for something
dictionaryExamples: The building was declared unfit for human habitation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cars also emit carbon monoxide and make the air unfit to breath[e]. First Certificate in English; B2; Amharic

sense.def: to become open and flat, or to make something become open and flat

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, you will be if you saw our slide show and talk - members can hardly forget that relaxing afternoon when we unfolded the sails on the lake and enjoyed the tranquility of the area. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: If a situation or story unfolds, it develops or becomes known.
dictionaryExamples: The nation watched on TV as the tragic events unfolded.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The plot unfolds in an exciting way and the film is fraught with lies, surprises and insinuations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: not expected
dictionaryExamples: The concert was cancelled due to unforeseen circumstances.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, owing to unforeseen circumstances, the half-day visit to St Andrews was cancel[l]ed and I was told about it only in the late morning, which prevented me from doing what I had planned. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

dictionaryExamples: Seeing Niagara Falls was an unforgettable experience.

dictionaryExamples: One unfortunate person failed to see the hole and fell straight into it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was always an unfortunate person, because bad things happen[ed] to him all the time. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: used to say that you wish something was not true or had not happened
dictionaryExamples: I'd love to come, but unfortunately, I have to work.
Unfortunately, I didn't have my credit card with me or I'd certainly have bought it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately I lost my keys. Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: not friendly
dictionaryExamples: She was really unfriendly to me.

sense.def: sad

dictionaryExamples: I'm unhappy about the situation.

sense.def: likely to become ill or likely to damage your health

sense.def: not wanting to help someone, in a way that seems unfriendly

dictionaryExamples: an unhelpful remark

sense.def: a special set of clothes that are worn by people who do a particular job or go to a particular school
dictionaryExamples: a school uniform
a nurse's uniform

Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: not important
dictionaryExamples: Staffing is still a relatively unimportant issue compared to the other problems that we're facing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Surely there were some little problems but I think they were unimportant. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: If a place is uninhabited, no one lives there.
dictionaryExamples: an uninhabited island
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The house turned out to be uninhabited, as my brother had said. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: not interested
dictionaryExamples: He's completely uninterested in politics.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is uninterested in his father['s] money. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: not interesting

sense.def:
an organization that represents a group of people
    who do a particular job or who have the same goals

the American Civil Liberties Union

sense.def:
a single political unit that is made up of two or more
    countries, states, etc.

the European Union
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I visited the Soviet Union and spent a couple of days in Lvov. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: different from everyone and everything else

sense.def: unusual and special

International English Language Testing System; C1; Czech

sense.def: a single thing or a separate part of something larger

family unity
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would conclude by saying that [some] healthy competition is good, but your main goal has to be to work together as a group and work towards the achievement of goal[s] - as the saying goes, "united we stand, divided we fall" and unity is strength. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

a university course/professor

dictionaryExamples: an unnatural silence

sense.def: in a way that is not necessary
dictionaryExamples:

                         potential dangers.

sense.def: dangerous
dictionaryExamples: The building is unsafe.

dictionaryExamples: Many women feel unsafe on the streets at night.

sense.def: not good enough
dictionaryExamples: The excuse they gave was unsatisfactory.

dictionaryExamples: an unscrupulous financial adviser
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are loyal readers of your newspaper and we ask you to raise your voice in defen[s]e of our community against the unscrupulous sharks of big business. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: having no answer or solution
dictionaryExamples: an unsolved mystery/murder/crime
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Consequently, a lot of problems remained unsolved. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: An unspoiled place is beautiful because it has not been changed or damaged by people.
dictionaryExamples: an island with clean, unspoiled beaches

sense.def: not achieving what was wanted or intended
dictionaryExamples: They made several unsuccessful attempts to reach the men.
His application was unsuccessful.

sense.def: in a way that is not successful
dictionaryExamples: We tried unsuccessfully to climb the wall.

sense.def: not acceptable or right for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: The software blocks material that is unsuitable for children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If the date of [the] meeting is unsuitable for you, just inform me. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: not certain or having doubts
dictionaryExamples: I'm a little unsure about what to do.
I was unsure of the directions.
I was unsure what/how to tell them.

sense.def: without confidence
dictionaryExamples: He has been unsure of himself ever since he failed to get that job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, Kingshaw, normally weaker than Cooper, very sensitive, unsure of himself, has his ups, too, and comes, though very seldom, to feel determined and superior; when he climbs the rocks he is definitely head and shoulders above Cooper who hasn't a head for heights. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: causing damage to the environment by using more of something than can be replaced naturally
dictionaryExamples: unsustainable fishing methods

sense.def: Something that is unsustainable cannot continue at the same rate.
dictionaryExamples: The level of spending on health care is unsustainable.

sense.def: If something is unthinkable, it is so strange that you cannot imagine it will ever happen.
dictionaryExamples: Thirty years ago a no-smoking restaurant would have been unthinkable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays it is simply unthinkable to live without [a] computer. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

dictionaryExamples: I'm staying here until the end of June.

sense.def: not before a particular time or event
dictionaryExamples: We didn't get home until past midnight.
It doesn't open until 7:00.

Whisk the egg whites until they look white and fluffy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had always wanted to travel by plane to another country but I [di]dn't have the op[p]ortunity until I was eleven years old. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: as far as
dictionaryExamples: Go straight until you get to the four-way stop, then turn left.

sense.def: not before a particular time or event
dictionaryExamples: We won't start the meeting until Jeanne is here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We didn't stop laughing until the movie finished. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: not changed or damaged in any way
dictionaryExamples: Most of the island remains untouched by tourism.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The starting point is in Lokken, an idyl[l]ic fishing village b[eside] the North Sea, still untouched by tourism. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: false
dictionaryExamples: We knew the rumors were untrue.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They realized that almost everything mentioned in your advertisement appeared to be untrue. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: different and not ordinary, often in a way that is interesting or exciting
dictionaryExamples: an unusual situation/circumstance/occurrence

It's fairly unusual to keep insects as pets.
I was actually on time, which is very unusual for me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is about a dragon who is very kind and unusual! Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: not wanted
dictionaryExamples: an unwanted gift
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Children feel alone, unwanted and become very often latch-key children who come back to a sad home where nobody is waiting for them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: ill
dictionaryExamples: to feel/look unwell
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I won't be able to go to your English class tomorrow morning because my sister is unwell and I will have to stay with her. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: not wanting to do something
dictionaryExamples: A lot of people are unwilling to accept change.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was unwilling to face the truth and the reality that my best friend had already left me. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: in a way that shows that you do not want to do something
dictionaryExamples: He unwillingly agreed to take her home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a clash between two different cultures and mentalities. Unwillingly though, they accept them, probably due to the fact they are satisfied with their son becoming a real adult. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a state of not being willing to do something
dictionaryExamples: Both sides have shown unwillingness to negotiate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the 70s some women also beg[a]n to wear short skirts, which might be seen as a way to express their unwillingness to obey certain dress codes or as a symbol of their independence. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to relax, especially after working
dictionaryExamples: Music helps me to unwind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The houses will be semi-detached to [allow] neighbors to chat and unwind. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: If you unwind something, or if something unwinds, it stops being curled up or twisted around something else and is made straight.
dictionaryExamples: He unwound the bandage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Slowly, the doctor unwound the bandages revealing the two cotton patches covering her eyes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: stupid and likely to cause problems
dictionaryExamples: an unwise decision
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But we don't want to put too much pressure on them because this is unwise and the worst thing parents could do to their children. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: vertical or as straight as possible
dictionaryExamples: He stood up.
She opened her eyes and sat up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The whole] class stood up and sang "Imagine". Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: toward or in a higher place or position
dictionaryExamples: She looked up and smiled at me.
This road goes up into the Andes.
The water was up to the level of the windows.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As the concert finished, I heard someone call my name. I looked up and I saw my friend on the other side of the concert [hall]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: to walk directly toward someone or something until you are next to them
dictionaryExamples: He came straight up to me and introduced himself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She came up to him to help him with the luggage. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: not in bed
dictionaryExamples: I stayed up all night finishing this report.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That night we were up until late talking and after a couple of days she left. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: If an action or decision is up to someone, they are responsible for doing or making it.
dictionaryExamples: I can't decide for you, Jack, it's up to you.
It's up to Sophie to decide whether she wants to enter the competition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is my opinion but it's up to you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to be doing or planning something
dictionaryExamples: What have you been up to?
They're up to something - I can tell.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What have you been up to? Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: to a greater degree, amount, volume, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Please speak up. I can't hear you.
The heater warms the room up  within minutes.
The cost of car insurance is up, but not very much.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover the microphone suddenly wouldn't work anymore, and even though I desperately tried to speak up, people began to lose interest in both my speech and me and simply started to talk to each other instead. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: used to emphasize that an action or process is complete
dictionaryExamples: Come on, Maria, drink up your lemonade.
Who's going to clean up this mess?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anna, I broke one of your beautiful vase[s] accidentally when I was trying to clean up the house one evening. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: rising and falling
dictionaryExamples: They were jumping up and down with impatience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, you should be bouncing up and down with joy (just kidding)! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to or in a higher place or position
dictionaryExamples: He ran up the steps.
We followed her up the stairs to a large meeting room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We r[o]de up the mountain [on] our b[i]kes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: along or further along the street/road, etc.
dictionaryExamples: They live just up the street.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Go up the street and turn left on the square. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: any amount or number under 10, 20, etc.
dictionaryExamples: We can invite up to 65 people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A wedding can cost up to 10,000 SFr. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: until a particular time
dictionaryExamples: You can call me up until midnight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The party  will be in my house up to 1:00 a.m., then we will go to Jean's house. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: from one end to the other and back again
dictionaryExamples: They were running up and down the hallway.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only fifteen years ago, anyone who was seen walking alone down the street talking to himself was thought to be irrevo[c]ably mad, whereas nowadays we all stride up and down streets and corridors apparently muttering to the air. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: having all the most recent information about a subject or activity
dictionaryExamples: The course should bring you up to speed with the latest techniques.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apart [from] this you can keep yourself up to speed with what's happening around the world on various fronts. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: the way that your parents take care of you and the things that they teach you when you are growing up
dictionaryExamples: a strict religious/Catholic/Jewish upbringing
He described his upbringing on a farm in Kansas.
her  middle-class upbringing
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now, as a grown-up person, I am trying to evaluate [my] upbringing objectively. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: An upcoming event will happen soon.
dictionaryExamples: the upcoming elections
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is a good way to keep our members informed about upcoming events. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to add new information
dictionaryExamples: The website has just been updated.
We'll update you on this news story throughout the day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, I can also always update my knowledge by visiting the information and new technology websites on the Internet from time to time. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to make something more modern
dictionaryExamples: They need to update their image.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, the movies shown are updated regularly, I guess that part is under control. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: new information
dictionaryExamples: I'll need regular updates on your progress.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Television offers different programs, such as documentaries, programs on culture and updates on [the] news. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a new form of something that existed at an earlier time
dictionaryExamples: a software update
It's an update of an old 1960s movie.

sense.def: to improve something so that it is of a higher quality or is a newer model
dictionaryExamples: to upgrade a computer
The system has been upgraded.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The computer [has] upgraded most existing inventions, and made them more efficient, faster and [more] user friendl[y]. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a piece of software or equipment that improves the quality, power or usefulness of a computer or machine
dictionaryExamples: a hardware upgrade
The upgrade to version 5.0 costs $395.

sense.def: to agree with a decision, especially a legal one, and say it was correct
dictionaryExamples: The court upheld the ruling.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last but not least, governments around the world should pass and uphold stricter laws concerning environmental issues. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to support a decision, principle, or law
dictionaryExamples: Police officers are expected to uphold the law.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Additionally, some uphold the view that people living in [the] countryside face greater problems than those in towns. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the process or cost of keeping something in good condition, or of keeping a person or animal healthy
dictionaryExamples: The upkeep of a building like that must be very high.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In point of fact, after our early morning meeting at the community cente[r] we decided to resort, if nothing else helps, to raising money for the upkeep of the hospital at the expense of our pension. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to send a computer program or a document electronically from your computer, using the Internet
dictionaryExamples: All the files have been uploaded to the server.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should upload it [to] the website. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: at a higher position or level than something else
dictionaryExamples: the upper lip/body
The office building's upper floors were being repainted.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am doing the upper intermediate level and last summer I was in London [for] three months. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be in a stronger position than someone else so that you control a situation
dictionaryExamples: Government troops are gradually gaining the upper hand over the rebels.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Humans vs. machines - who has the upper hand? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the social group consisting of the people of the highest social class, who are usually rich
dictionaryExamples: The upper class usually send their children to expensive private schools.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've just chosen to travel south and back in time to be a Roman lady, belonging to the upper class of course, living an easy life full of pleasure.  Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: belonging to or relating to the upper class
dictionaryExamples: The novel criticizes the upper-class way of life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Talking about fashion, one always tends to think of glamorous designer dresses, catwalks in Paris, Rome or New York, and upper-class societies, able to spend huge amounts of money on luxurious clothing. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: straight up or vertical
dictionaryExamples: Please return your seats to an upright position and fasten your seat belts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Immediately the pilot informed the passengers that the weather conditions were not good and [told us] to fasten our seatbelt, put the seat upright and [ado]pt the emergency position. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: unhappy or worried because something unpleasant has happened
dictionaryExamples: They'd had an argument and she was still upset about it.
Mike got very upset when I told him the news.
She was very upset to hear that the trip had been canceled.
He was very upset that you didn't reply to his messages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was upset that you didn't come to my birthday party. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: an illness in the stomach
dictionaryExamples: I had an upset stomach last night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wasn't feeling well at all with an upset stomach and headache. First Certificate in English; B2; Norwegian

sense.def: to make someone feel unhappy or worried
dictionaryExamples: The phone call had clearly upset her.
It still upsets him when he thinks about the accident.
Don't upset yourself by thinking about what might have happened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This really upset me as no notice w[as] given before the show. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: having the part that is usually at the top turned to be at the bottom
dictionaryExamples: Turn the jar upside down and shake it.
One car landed on its side and the other was upside down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The furniture was upside down and neither money nor cash were left. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: on or to a higher level of a building
dictionaryExamples: He ran upstairs to answer the phone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I forget something, I don't have to go upstairs. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: on or at a higher level of a building
dictionaryExamples: an upstairs window
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly, Robert [and I] heard a strange noise coming from an upstairs room but we kept on reading quietly. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: modern, recent, or containing the latest information
dictionaryExamples: Visit our website for up-to-date information on movie times.
It is essential to have an up-to-date dictionary.
The Internet keeps us up to date.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will write more later - I do need to give you up-to-date information on my love life! First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: moving toward a higher place or level
dictionaryExamples: an upward glance
an upward trend in sales
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The oldest group registers a steady upward movement in terms of attendance. (1802604; International English Language Testing System; Philippines; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2005; Tagalog; 7

sense.def: toward a higher position, level, or value
dictionaryExamples: The cost of completion has been revised upward again due to inflation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The pattern begins to go upward from 2002 to present with only 35-49 groups and 50+ groups. International English Language Testing System; C1; Korean

sense.def: belonging or relating to a town or city
dictionaryExamples: urban areas
urban development
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are generally more interested in [an] urban lifestyle than [living in] the countryside. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: very important and needing you to take action immediately
dictionaryExamples: an urgent message
He has to sign that paper - will you tell him it's urgent?
Many people are in urgent need of food and water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He said that my school principal would like to see me that day and it was urgent. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: in a way that is urgent
dictionaryExamples: Help is urgently needed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have e-mailed you to tell you that I need your bicycle urgently. Preliminary English Test; B1; Nepali

sense.def: used after a verb or preposition to refer to the person who is speaking or writing and one or more other people
dictionaryExamples: She gave us all a present.
Thank you for driving us to the airport.
Would you like to have dinner with us next Saturday?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our teacher talks to us and gives us some questions. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Spanish

sense.def: the way that words are used
dictionaryExamples: a guide to English grammar and usage
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That is why I couldn't solve all my problems with English usage. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: the amount of something that is used, or the way that something is used
dictionaryExamples: restrictions on water usage
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have therefore decided that, at our company, we will try to keep our energy usage as low as possible. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: If you use something, you do something with it for a particular purpose.
dictionaryExamples: Can I use your pen, please?
Do you use your computer much?
I paid for the tickets using my credit card.
She uses her car for work.
Nick used the money to buy a CD player.
Use scissors to cut the shapes out.
It gave me a chance to use my skills.
The old hospital isn't used any more.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She uses the Internet every day. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: to take an  amount from a supply of something
dictionaryExamples: Taking a shower uses less water than taking a bath.
These bulbs use a lot of electricity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The equipment in the kitchen is very old and use[s] a lot of electricity and gas. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish

sense.def: to say or write a particular word or phrase
dictionaryExamples: "Autumn" is used in British English, but "fall" is the usual word in American English.

sense.def: to treat someone badly in order to get what you want
dictionaryExamples: He was just using me to so he could meet the director.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What a horrible thing to do, just using people - especially him! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

blocks.phrasalVerb: use up sth or use sth up

sense.def: to finish a supply of something
dictionaryExamples: Don't use up all the milk - we need some for breakfast.
The Earth's resources are being used up at an alarming rate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It saves time which would be used up [by] doing housework such as laundry, cleaning  and ironing. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: when you use something, or when something is being used
dictionaryExamples: an increase in the use of mobile phones
Guests have free use of the swimming pool.
Turn the machine off when it's not in use.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There's a very good book. It's [called] "English grammar in use". Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: a purpose for which something is used
dictionaryExamples: A food processor has a variety of uses in the kitchen.
I'd have no use for a boat.
The land was no good for farming, but he found other uses for it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We  need computers in many places, and [for] many uses today. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: one of the meanings of a word, or the way that a particular word is used
dictionaryExamples: Can you list all the uses of the word "point"?

sense.def: to be useful
dictionaryExamples: Is this bag of any use to you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope my remarks [will] be of some use. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to not be useful
dictionaryExamples: His advice turned out to be no use at all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mother came immediately, but it was no use because my brother isn't afraid of her, so she called my father.  First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say that trying to do something has no effect
dictionaryExamples: It was no use talking to him - he just wouldn't listen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was no use [trying to] smoke cigarettes in this pub. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to use something that is available
dictionaryExamples: We were encouraged to make use of all the facilities.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I think the designers will make use of the raw materials and create an innovative look for all of us. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: permission to use something, or the ability to use something
dictionaryExamples: Martin has offered me the use of his car.
He lost the use of his left arm in the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of my closest friend[s] who lost the use of her legs five years ago in a tragic car accident took part [in] this trip. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: not new and owned by someone else  before you
dictionaryExamples: We're looking for a good used car.
a store that sells used books
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have not much money to spend and I buy always used cds. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: helping you to do or achieve something
dictionaryExamples: useful information/advice
A good knife is probably one of the most useful things you can have in a kitchen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has a camera and it is very useful. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: the quality of being useful
dictionaryExamples: He explained the usefulness of having a Wi-Fi connection.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They came back yesterday and I have interviewed them to find out what they think about the usefulness of the program. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: If something is useless, it does not work well or it has no effect.
dictionaryExamples: This umbrella's useless - there's a big hole in it.
It's useless arguing with her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I started digging, but it was useless. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: having no skill in an activity
dictionaryExamples: She wanted help with the math but I'm just useless!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every time I see her, she seems to be busy sewing, knitting, etc. In this I really envy her, I'm quite useless at making clothes, although I can certainly do adjustments on my clothes, make curtains an[d] such things. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who uses a product, machine or service
dictionaryExamples: drug users
More than a million people are daily users of the subway system.
When you log in, you will be asked for your user name and password.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to meet other experienced computer users in order to share programs as well as tips and tricks about programming. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: in the way that most often happens
dictionaryExamples: He usually gets home about 6 o'clock.
I usually just have a sandwich for lunch.
Is he usually so rude?
"Is the drugstore open on Sundays?" "Usually."
I'm not usually so tired.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hungarian people usually eat breakfast at 6 or 7 o'clock. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Hungarian

sense.def: used to emphasize how important or serious something is
dictionaryExamples: a matter of the utmost importance
The situation needs to be handled with the utmost care.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion, there are features of utmost importance that should be [careful]ly checked. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to try as hard as you can to do something
dictionaryExamples: We did our utmost to finish the project on time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, we l[i]ve in a materialistic society where we all do our utmost in order to make ends meet, but we are never satisfied. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: used to emphasize something
dictionaryExamples: She dismissed the article as utter nonsense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To act otherwise would be, in my opinion, utter nonsense. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to say something
dictionaryExamples: She left without uttering a word.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After I had told him about it, he was in such despair that he was not able to utter a single word. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: completely
dictionaryExamples: It's utterly ridiculous.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The information provided in your report about the final goal was utterly wrong. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish
